TopicTitle: Can somebody calculate the Kinetic Energy for me?

Articles.Content:
Hi!

I was messin' around in KSP the other day and started thinking about what kinetic energy my ship would actually produce at max velocity.

So i wonder, would anyone be nice and help me by calculating the KE. ( i do not understand the formula with my basic math degree )

So what i have is the mass and the maximum velocity.

Velocity = 1181.8 m/s or 4254,48 km/h (not sure if right, my math is not that good )

Mass = 1.04 tons or 1040 kilos.

Hopeful for answers!
KE=1/2MV2, so it's 1/2 X 1040 X (11822). That comes out to 7.3X108J, or 727MJ

If you want to input with words instead of using a calculator Wolfram Alpha can: http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=kinetic+energy+of+1040+kg+object+travelling+at+1181.8+m%2Fs

Also has data on our real Solar system http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=distance+between+earth+comet+67P+tomorrow

F=M*A

So,

Force = 943.472Kg * 1181.8 m/s/s = 1,114,995.2096 Net Force.

So, about 1,114Kn of Newtons. If you want Kinetic Energy, I think the equation is 1 / 2 * Mass * Velocity ^2. So the square of the speed (1,181.8m/s squared is 1,396,651.24) multiplied by mass (943.472Kg * 1.3mill = 1317701338.71), multiplied by the constant 1/2 comes out to 658,850,669.353 Joules of Kinetic Energy.

Edit: I should note that I used short tons for the conversion from Tons to Kg. Kryten did not, which explains the difference and why Kryten got 727MJ.

Edited September 16, 2014 by WestAir

West air, F=MA is not the equation to use.

V != A

What you inadvertently calculated (although with the wrong labels), is momentum, which is Mass* Velocity.

West air, F=MA is not the equation to use.

V != A

What you inadvertently calculated (although with the wrong labels), is momentum, which is Mass* Velocity.

Did I at least get it with the second equation?
Not quite, because KSP uses metric tons, not short tons. It was programmed by Mexicans, remember.
That and the OP specified the number of kilograms...
To be fair he did use the wrong spelling for tonnes so that may be where the confusion arose.
I had to look up 'short ton'.. seriously, imperial system Converting between various units is something I do regularly at work, I'd lose my wits if I had to use those measures
You should always default to metric for any kind of physics calculation. No exceptions.

You should always default to metric for any kind of physics calculation. No exceptions.

Fixed for you.

Fixed for you.

Inclined to agree, but we sometimes have to throw our less fortunate friends in the US a bone.
In my defense, google calculator automatically uses short tons instead of metric.
That's because tons are the imperial unit. 1000kg = 1 tonne = 1.1 tons. Pronounced the same, spelled differently.
I feel like we should just pay the money to do away with imperial units.

I feel like we should just pay the money to do away with imperial units.

Your avatar would suggest you do not like anything Imperial. Long live the Republic!
